entry.title: SAP TM – Using BP Goods Receiving Hours instead of Calendar Resource
entry.content:
SAP TM – Using BP Goods Receiving Hours instead of Calendar Resource

In SAP TM, operating times define when a location—such as a customer site—is available for transportation activities like loading and unloading. These time windows are crucial for accurate planning, ensuring that carriers only schedule arrivals when the location is open to receive goods.

Operating times are typically maintained using Calendar Resource | SAP Help Portal  which specify the working days, hours, and any exceptions (e.g., holidays) but also other possibility is available using the Goods Receiving Hours maintained at the business partner level could be used directly, rather than defining separate calendar resources for each location.

For SAP S/4HANA releases up to 2022: SAP TM transportation planning can be enhanced through an implicit enhancement spot implementation to use business partner 'goods receiving hour' definitions instead of calendar resources at ship-to locations. This enhancement does not require modification to the shipped TM standard coding, though implementation of an implicit enhancement spot is necessary  1763253 - Using BP Goods Receiving Hours instead of Calendar Resource - SAP for Me

For releases 2023 and onwards: A new BAdI is provided that allows operating times to be adjusted in embedded scheduling, the VSR optimizer, and TRS scheduling. An example implementation reads the goods receiving hours of the business partner for the destination location and source locations 3637383 - BAdI to allow manipulating opening hours considered by scheduling, VSR and TRS - SAP for Me.

Configuration Approaches

The goods receiving hours can be configured for different scenarios:

  • Reading goods receiving hours for business partners of both source and destination locations
  • Reading goods receiving hours only for business partners of type customer  

Important point the new BadI “/SCMTMS/PLN_OT_EXAMPLE”needs to be activated to be call during the planning mentioned in the Oss Note 3637383 - BAdI to allow manipulating opening hours considered by scheduling, VSR and TRS - SAP for Me.

A CDS view I_BPGoodsReceivingHoursVH is also available for basic goods receiving hours data, SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition SAP Business Accelerator Hub

Now let’s run an example of 2 sales order with 2 customer which have different time of Goods Receiving Hours:

Customer 1:

Customer 2:

In the Transportation Cockpit we can see 2 Freight Units for one for each client to be delivery on 04/09/25 in this case it’s “Thursday”, but customer only accepts to received goods on Fridays which in this case is 05/09/25.

So, when we plan it into a Freight Order based on the Planning Profile setups we got the follow results:

This possibility using BP Goods Receiving Hours instead of Calendar Resource should be carefully review and test massive with the optimizer and manual planning to ensure the performance not have side effect during the Transportation Planning and consider the volume of master data to be maintain.

Consider both Oss Notes according with you S4/HANA version for the SAP TM.

1763253 - Using BP Goods Receiving Hours instead of Calendar Resource - SAP for Me

3637383 - BAdI to allow manipulating opening hours considered by scheduling, VSR and TRS - SAP for Me.

Hope this help you!

Thank you and regards.

Rogerio Lima.

entry.title: Using SAP CALM Features App to Track Transports in the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition
entry.content:
Introduction

Recently I was exploring the capabilities of the SAP Cloud ALM (CALM) and their applications to the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, and found out we can use the Features app to track or document changes through transports.  This blog intends to use a video recording to showcase this new capability working in tandem.

 

Background

During the implementation of the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, we can create a project to guide us through the entire process, especially we can import the SAP Activate content to follow through. This project can be a big new implementation taking months to complete, or just adding a new feature from SAP’s latest innovation to be achieved in a few days.

For each project, we will associate with the cloud tenants.  For example, I define a 3 System Landscape in the below picture:

  • Development Tenant: Dev-100, Dev-080
  • Quality Assurance: TST-100
  • Production: PRD-100

Define a System Group with Relevant Systems in the CALM

 

After a project and its associate Deployment Landscape is defined, we can use the Features app to document and track the changes.  You can find the Features app with a truck icon from the Implementation tab, in the "Design, Build, Test, Deploy" block.

 

Demo

This demo is executed on four tenants: Dev-100, TST-100, PRD-100 and CALM. To get the point across, I create a simple user defined Business Role and add it to a dedicated Software Collection to export.  This export creates a transport to be imported to TST-100 and PRD-100.

In the first half of the demo, we go through all the steps without involvement of the CALM.  In the second half of the demo, from importing the transport to the TST-100, I start using the Features app of the CALM.

The demo is recorded and listed in the Reference section. Here is the recording timestamps and their corresponding steps.

Conclusion

With this demo, you can find a good use case of using SAP CALM to document and record your changes via transport(s) in the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition for the good record keeping purpose.

entry.content:
Hello @Charisma_fitra 

The error You cannot maintain S/N in bin items because the S/N profile is missing" occurs when attempting to post a Goods Receipt for a serial-number–managed product into a warehouse bin, but the serial number profile is not correctly maintained or is unsupported in that warehouse process.

Why it occurs

  • In the public cloud, serial number management must be configured in the product master.
  • If the product does not have a serial number profile assigned, the system cannot generate or accept serial numbers during goods receipt.
  • Some warehouse-managed storage types or processes don’t permit serial number entry at bin level unless the profile is active.

How to resolve the issue

Check the Product Master

    • App: Manage Product Master Data.
    • Open your product → go to General → Serial Number.
    • Assign a valid Serial Number Profile MMSL for goods movements

Check Warehouse Process

    • App: Manage Your Solution and Configuration Activities.
    • Verify whether the warehouse storage type and process type support serial number handling. Not all standard processes support S/N at bin level in Public Cloud.

During Goods Receipt

  • Enter the serial numbers manually in the Goods Receipt screen, or

entry.title: Re: SAP AVC Need to update the Bom qnty based on characte...
entry.content:
Hello @ankit_1662 

Got it, I can see why you’re getting the syntax error in your procedure.

From your screenshots:

  • Characteristic AVC_ANCHO1 is defined as Numeric Format, 3 characters, 2 decimals.
  • In the dependency editor, you’re writing:

QTY = quantity($ROOT.AVC_ANCHO1 : 0.01 , 'PC');

and receiving error E28024 – Syntax error in simple action/procedure (line 1).

The issue

In SAP variant configuration dependencies (procedures, actions, preconditions):

  • quantity() expects a numeric expression, not a characteristic reference with “: 0.01”.
  • The colon syntax is not valid here.
  • Also, units like 'PC' are optional if the characteristic already has a unit defined.

Correct syntax examples

If your characteristic is numeric:

QTY = $ROOT.AVC_ANCHO1.

QTY = $ROOT.AVC_ANCHO1 / 0.01.

QTY = quantity($ROOT.AVC_ANCHO1 , 'PC').

Recommendation

  1. Since AVC_ANCHO1 already has Unit = PC in its definition, you can just use:

QTY = $ROOT.AVC_ANCHO1.

2.Only use quantity()if you want to assign a different unit than the characteristic default.

 

So, replace your code with:

QTY = $ROOT.AVC_ANCHO1.

That should clear the syntax error.

Let me know how it goes

With regards

Chuma

entry.title: Agentic AI in SAP Exception Management
entry.content:
Agentic AI in SAP Exception Management

Introduction:

Enterprises running SAP can relate to this moment: month-end is approaching, the finance team is reconciling accounts, the procurement is chasing approvals, and the operations are working overtime to close orders. Then it happens: an exception surfaces. A blocked invoice. A missing goods receipt. A foreign currency posting that doesn’t add up.

From the eagle eye view this might seem just a minor technical error. But the reality? They halt business processes, disrupt vendor payments, distort financial reporting, and expose the enterprise to compliance risks.

For example: A global retail enterprise once faced an inventory discrepancy exception. In SAP, the system records showed stock available for sale, but in reality, the physical warehouse had no such stock. This type of exception occurs in SAP Materials Management (MM) and Inventory Management (IM), and often spreads into Production Planning (PP) and Sales & Distribution (SD) because customer orders are created based on inaccurate stock levels.

The impact was significant: customers placed orders that couldn’t be fulfilled, leading to stockouts during peak season. Operations teams scrambled to explain, procurement rushed to source emergency materials, and finance recorded lost revenue. In just one quarter, the company estimated over USD 3 million in lost sales, in addition to reputational damage and strained customer relationships.

In this digital world where uptime, accuracy and punctuality define competitiveness, an exception like this becomes a huge boardroom issue and requires modern and proactive solutions to tackle.\

Exceptions in SAP – A Business Reality

An exception in SAP is basically a deviation from the expected process flow which required a manual intervention to fix. These exceptions are often unplanned and disrupt the business operations.

Example 1 Retail (Inventory Exception)

A major retail chain launched a seasonal promotion on consumer electronics. SAP showed 5,000 units available in the system (MM/IM module), but the actual warehouse had only 3,000 units due to a stock posting error. Orders were processed based on the system quantity, and customers kept buying online, only to later receive cancellation notices.

  • Where it happened: SAP Materials Management (MM), Inventory Management (IM)
  • Business Impact:
    • USD 2M in lost revenue during the campaign due to unfulfilled orders.
    • Surge in refund processing workload for customer service teams.
    • Brand trust damage, with social media backlash during peak season.

Example 2 Pharmaceuticals (Batch Exception):

In a pharmaceutical company’s SAP QM (Quality Management), a batch of life-saving drugs nearing expiry was incorrectly flagged as “released” for sale instead of being quarantined. This happened due to a QM inspection lot error linked to inventory postings in SAP IM. Thousands of packs were shipped before the mistake was detected.

  • Where it happened: SAP Quality Management (QM), Inventory Management (IM)
  • Business Impact:
    • Immediate batch recall costing USD 2M, including reverse logistics.
    • Brand damage in a highly regulated market, eroding customer confidence.
    • FDA and EMA scrutiny, increasing audit frequency and compliance costs.

Example 3 (Finance):

An invoice is posted in USD, but the corresponding goods receipt is in EUR. A mismatch beyond tolerance blocks the posting. The vendor goes unpaid, relationships sour, and the CFO gets an unwelcome escalation.

Example 4 (Procurement):

A purchase order is unreleased because the approval strategy wasn’t configured. The production line waits three days for materials, leading to penalty clauses from a late delivery. In the both cases the business outcome is clear: delays, costs, and risks.

In all the above cases the business outcome is clear: delays, costs, and risks.

Best Practices in Exception Management

Over time, organizations running SAP have realized that exceptions have to be managed intelligently. The most successful enterprises have moved from reactive “firefighting” to proactive, preventive strategies that make exception handling part of business resilience.

entry.title: SAP Databricks: Create inferences for application integration with SAP Build Apps
entry.content:
Part 1 – SQL analytics with SAP Data Products
Part 2 – Build and deploy Mosaic AI and Agent Tools
Part 3 – How to use AutoML to forecast sales data
Part 4 – Connect SAP Data Products with non-SAP data from AWS S3
Part 5 – End-to-end integration: SAP Databricks, SAP Datasphere, and SAP Analytics Cloud
Part 6 – Create inferences for application integration with SAP Build 

Create inferences for application integration with SAP Build Apps

In the earlier parts of the series, we explored the capabilities of SAP Databricks - from running SQL analytics and leveraging AutoML, to building end-to-end data integration with SAC. Now, we're taking things a step further.

In this post, the focus shifts from model development to real-world application - specifically, how to extend trained and deployed ML models into interactive, user-facing applications.

We’ll walk through how to:

  • Leverage data products from Unity Catalog and enhance them using notebooks
  • Serve a trained ML model for real-time inference
  • Use SAP Build Apps (low-code/no-code) to rapidly build a front-end interface that interacts with the model for inference

By integrating SAP Databricks with SAP Build Apps, we extend the powerful capabilities of notebooks into the creation of intelligent applications, enabling machine learning experiences to directly benefit end users. With SAP Build Apps, it's quick and easy to prototype and bring these ML-powered experiences to life, even without deep frontend development expertise.

 

1. Data Preparation and Feature Engineering

The goal is to train a machine learning model to predict sales order lead times based on inputs such as product, order date, and quantity. In my environment, I accessed the sales order data products from the SAP Databricks Unity Catalog, which was delta-shared from S/4 HANA.

The data was cleaned and preprocessed by addressing missing or inconsistent values, particularly focusing on improving the accuracy of the delivery dates. Relevant features were also added to enhance the dataset, including order lead time, day of the week, and month.

 

Once the data is cleaned up, I saved this back into the Unity Catalog as a delta table. Saving the cleaned and feature engineered table allows you to manage and share datasets across your teams with access control. By storing the processed table here, I could easily access it for model training, and downstream tasks while maintaining version control and consistency.

 

2. Model Training

I used XGBoost to train a model to predict the lead time based on the features. You can use any ML models that suits your use case or take a look at how to run AutoML experiments in Part 3 (link).

 

3. Mosaic AI Model Serving

Mosaic AI Model Serving offers a unified platform to deploy, manage, and run AI/ML models for both real-time and batch predictions. Once deployed, each model is exposed as a REST API that can be easily integrated into web or client applications.

The model being deployed here is a Custom Model, built using Python and trained with standard machine learning libraries or custom code. It is packaged in the MLflow format and can be registered in the SAP Databricks workspace model registry as a Python pyfunc model.

Package your model into a Python class that can be called easily:

# Model wrapper class for XGBoost regression to predict LeadTime
import mlflow.pyfunc
import pandas as pd
from mlflow.models.signature import ModelSignature
from mlflow.types import Schema, ColSpec


class LeadTimeModel(mlflow.pyfunc.PythonModel):
    def __init__(self, model_pipeline):
        self.model_pipeline = model_pipeline

    def predict(self, context, model_input):
        # Convert input to pandas DataFrame regardless of input type
        if isinstance(model_input, pd.DataFrame):
            input_df = model_input
        elif isinstance(model_input, dict):
            input_df = pd.DataFrame([model_input])
        else:
            input_df = pd.DataFrame(model_input)
        predictions = self.model_pipeline.predict(input_df)
        return pd.DataFrame({'predicted_lead_time': predictions})

# Define input and output schema
input_feature_names = [
    "SalesOrderDayOfWeek",
    "SalesOrderDay",
    "SalesOrderMonth",
    "SalesOrderItemText",
    "OrderQuantity"
]
input_schema = Schema([
    ColSpec("string", "SalesOrderDayOfWeek"),
    ColSpec("long", "SalesOrderDay"),
    ColSpec("long", "SalesOrderMonth"),
    ColSpec("string", "SalesOrderItemText"),
    ColSpec("long", "OrderQuantity")
])
output_schema = Schema([ColSpec("long", "predicted_lead_time")])
signature = ModelSignature(inputs=input_schema, outputs=output_schema)

input_example = pd.DataFrame([{
    "SalesOrderDayOfWeek": "Monday",
    "SalesOrderDay": 13,
    "SalesOrderMonth": 8,
    "SalesOrderItemText": "Y120 Bike",
    "OrderQuantity": 5
}])

with mlflow.start_run():
    mlflow.pyfunc.log_model(
        "lead-time-pred", 
        python_model=LeadTimeModel(model_pipeline), 
        input_example=input_example, 
        signature=signature, 
        registered_model_name="lead-time-prediction"
    )

SAP Build Apps enables quick app development with a low-code platform, allowing you to create custom applications. In this section, we'll demonstrate how we can rapidly prototype a user interface to interact with the deployed model.

Use the REST API integration to establish a connection with SAP Databricks. Once the destination service is created, you can access it via the SAP Build Apps.

In the Integration tab, specify the relative path and query for the model, then run tests on the API to check your connection.

 

Build the UI with the drag and drop interface.

Conclusion

The application design may vary depending on its complexity and the steps required to make it production-ready. To manage connections and handle additional logic, a backend would be needed. However, this demonstrates how to enhance a data product, serving the ML model on SAP Databricks for inference and connecting it to SAP Build Apps via API, providing a foundation to extend and build your own intelligent applications.

entry.content:
There is no standard report that neatly displays milestone billing plan details like Sales Order Number, Billing Plan, Billing Status, and Billing Amount all in one place. You can create a custom report considering the below tables

  • Sales Order Header & Item: Tables VBAK, VBAP
  • Billing Plan: Table FPLT (dates), FPLT_V (status), FPLT_S (amounts)
  • Billing Document: Table VBRK, VBRP

This gives you full control over layout and filters. You can include milestone dates, billing rules, and actual invoice status.

In SAP S/4HANA Cloud, you have Fiori App: Manage Sales Orders – Version 2 but this App is more of transactional than analytical. You won’t get a consolidated report view unless extended via CDS views or embedded analytics. So what you can do is create a custom CDS view that joins billing plan data with sales orders and billing documents. This can be exposed in:

  • Fiori apps
  • SAP Analytics Cloud
  • Excel via OData

This is the most modern and scalable approach if you're in a cloud or hybrid setup.

entry.title: Re: Make To Stock MRP set up for each sales order require...
entry.content:
Why SAP combines requirements is because, in MTS, SAP treats sales orders as forecast consumption, not as individual triggers for production. So when multiple sales orders exist for the same date, MRP sees them as one net requirement and creates a single planned order.

In order to split the order, Go to MM02 → MRP4 view, Set Ind/Collective Indicator = 2 (Individual requirements only). This tells MRP to treat each sales order separately—even in MTS.

Lot size EX allows grouping of requirements. Switch to FX and set Lot Size = 1 to force one planned order per requirement. This ensures MRP doesn’t combine quantities.

If configuration alone doesn’t meet your needs, implement logic in BAdI MD_ADD_ELEMENTS - Method ADD_CHANGE_ELEMENTS. You can write logic to split planned orders based on sales order number, even if dates match.

entry.title: Avoiding Common Pitfalls in Your SAP S/4HANA Migration: The Archiving Imperative
entry.content:
Migrating to SAP S/4HANA is more than a technical upgrade—it’s a strategic transformation. It’s an opportunity to rethink how your organization manages data for performance, compliance, and cost efficiency. Yet, one critical area is often overlooked: data archiving.

Handled well, archiving can reduce database size, accelerate migration, lower licensing costs, and ensure compliance with regulations like GDPR. But when neglected or mismanaged, it can lead to delays, inflated costs, and operational risks.

Here are five common mistakes enterprises make—and how to avoid them:

 

1. Undefined Objectives and Retention Strategy

The Pitfall: Many organizations begin archiving without clear goals. Is the aim to reduce database size, improve system performance, or meet compliance requirements? Without defined objectives, projects lose focus and fail to deliver value.

Industry Insight: A missing data residence strategy—rules for how long data remains in the system—leads to inconsistent practices and compliance gaps.

Examples:

  • A global manufacturing firm archived data without aligning with legal retention periods, resulting in audit penalties.
  • A retail company tried to reduce DB size but didn’t define scope—archived only 5% of eligible data.

How to Avoid It:

  • Set measurable goals (e.g., “Reduce DB size by 40% pre-migration”).
  • Define retention policies aligned with legal and business needs.
  • Document scope early (objects, years, entities).
  • Engage compliance and audit teams from the start.

 

2. Treating Archiving as a Technical Task Only

The Pitfall: When archiving is seen as an IT-only initiative, business users often resist, fearing loss of access to historical data. This can stall progress or lead to partial rollbacks.

Industry Insight: Business trust is essential. If users don’t believe in the archive, they won’t support the migration.

Examples:

  • A finance team blocked archiving because they weren’t shown how to retrieve archived invoices for audits.
  • A pharma company rolled back archiving after users couldn’t access clinical trial data due to poor communication.

How to Avoid It:

  • Position archiving as a joint business-IT effort.
  • Communicate clearly: data isn’t deleted—it’s managed smarter.
  • Offer intuitive access tools (e.g., ArchiveLink, OpenText viewers).
  • Start with a pilot to demonstrate value.

 

3. Inadequate Testing and Validation

The Pitfall: Assuming archiving will work out-of-the-box can result in broken workflows and inaccessible documents post go-live.

Industry Insight: Lack of testing is a top reason for post-migration issues. Archiving needs the same rigor as any other system change.

Examples:

  • A healthcare provider couldn’t retrieve patient billing records due to missing archive links.
  • A bank failed to validate tax reports post-archiving, triggering regulatory scrutiny.

How to Avoid It:

  • Build automated test cases for archive retrieval and reporting.
  • Include business users in UAT.
  • Test across systems (ECC, S/4, OpenText).
  • Validate legal compliance outputs (tax, audit, GDPR).

 

4. Skipping Specialized Tools and Expert Help

The Pitfall: Relying on manual setups or inexperienced teams to save costs often backfires, leading to misconfigurations and audit failures.

Industry Insight: Expert guidance and specialized tools streamline the process and reduce risk.

Examples:

  • A consumer goods company used manual archiving and missed ILM rules—resulting in data retention violations.
  • A financial services firm used PBS add-ons and reduced archiving time by 60%.

How to Avoid It:

  • Use policy-driven tools for retention and destruction.
  • Engage consultants with proven S/4HANA migration experience.
  • Consider add-ons like PBS, Neev, Auritas, or TJC for advanced capabilities.
  • Automate archiving with ILM policies and scheduled jobs.

 

Archiving isn’t just a checkbox—it’s a strategic enabler in your S/4HANA journey. Done right, it:

  • Cuts migration time and cost
  • Boosts system performance
  • Ensures regulatory compliance
  • Builds user confidence in the new platform

Avoiding these pitfalls requires early planning, strong governance, and cross-functional collaboration. Make archiving a priority—not an afterthought.ar

entry.title: Inflation Accounting in Türkiye – Index-Based Asset Revaluation in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition
entry.content:
With SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508, SAP now supports a significant legal requirement in Türkiye: index-based asset revaluation. (Inflation Accounting).

This regulation, mandated by Turkish tax and commercial law, requires companies to revalue their fixed assets based on monthly inflation indices published by the Turkish Statistical Institute (TÜİK).
This blog provides an overview of the legal requirement and explains how to meet it by demonstrating the implementation steps for a sample scenario.

About Index-Based Asset Revaluation in Türkiye

Index-based asset revaluation is a legal requirement in Türkiye introduced under the Vergi Usul Kanunu Genel Tebliği (Sıra No: 555), published in the Official Gazette (issue 32415, 30.12.2023).
This regulation requires companies to adjust their financial statements based on producer price indices published by TÜİK (Turkish Statistical Institute).

The calculation of the adjustment coefficient is defined in Article 17 of the Vergi Usul Kanunu Genel Tebliği (Sıra No: 555), published in the official Gazette (Resmi Gazete, issue 32415, 30.12.2023):

  • Five decimal places must be considered in the calculation.
  • The fifth digit must be rounded based on the sixth digit.

The official index values can be found here.

Note: Each customer is responsible for ensuring that the maintained index values and resulting calculations (including rounding) comply with the legal requirements!

 

Implementation Guide

This section explains the implementation steps of index-based revaluation in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition for a sample scenario involving a simple asset. It lists the steps required to complete the set-up, posting, valuation checks, a partial retirement, and (optionally) a reversal.

Note:

  • The revaluation is not carried out in a separate depreciation area, but within the valuation view where the index is assigned (e.g. 1 = Book Depreciation, 15 = Local Tax).
  • Customers should not use the scope item for additional depreciation areas for this purpose, as adding extra areas does not support the revaluation process and will not provide the intended outcome.

Scenario Details

  • Asset APC: 12,000 TRY
  • Useful life: 10 years (120 periods)
  • Valuation view: The view where the index is assigned (e.g., 1 = Book Depreciation or 15 = Local Tax)
  • Revaluation index: Monthly index (assigned before acquisition)
  • Scenario extension: Partial retirement of 70% on 01 Mach 2025; optional reversal of postings

Prerequisites

Maintain G/L account determination for revaluation in the Assign G/L Accounts (ID: 102622) configuration activity.

Step-by-Step Procedure

  1. Create revaluation index
    1. Open the Maintain Asset Revaluation Index app and create a new index with the following details:
      1. Revaluation Index ID: Freely selectable (e.g. INF_TR)
      2. Index Type: Replacement Value, Monthly
      3. Unit of Measure: Index Points
    2. Maintain the monthly index values published by TÜİK: TÜIK Inflation and Price Statistics

    3. Activate the revaluation index by clicking on "Activate" to make it available for valuation views.

       

  2. Maintain asset master data
    1. Open the Manage Fixed Assets app.
    2. Create a new asset and maintain all mandatory values (cost centre, profit centre, segment) and other values relevant to your business.
    3. Under Valuation → General Parameters, assign the revaluation index created in step 1.


    4. Adjust the useful life (in years) if necessary, for example, 10 years.
    5. Apply changes and save.

  3. Post acquisition of the asset
    1. In the Manage Fixed Assets app, choose Post → Post Acquisition → Acquisition (Net).

       

    2. In the new window, specify values for the following mandatory fields:
      1.          Journal Entry Date, Posting Date, Asset Value Date
      2.          Amount Posted in Transaction Currency (12,000 TRY in our example)
      3.          Year of Acquisition (Prior Year in our example)
    3. Choose Simulate to check the postings and then choose Post.

  4. View depreciation amounts
    1. In the Managed Fixed Assets app, go to Valuation to review the effects of revaluation.
    2. Under Value Display → Depreciation, you will see both the regular depreciation and the additional revaluation amounts

      Fiscal Year 2024:

      Fiscal Year 2025:

Scenario Extension: The asset was acquired in July 2024 for 12,000 TRY. In March 2025, 70% of the asset needs to be retired.

  1. In the Manage Fixed Assets app, choose Post → Post Retirement → Retirement without Revenue.


  2. Adjust the mandatory fields:
    • Journal Entry Date, Posting Date, Asset Value Date to 01.03.2025
    • Retirement Type: Partial Retirement by Percentage Rate
    • Retirement Percentage: 70 %
    • Year of Acquisition: Prior Year

    • Choose Post.
    • The results can be viewed under Valuation.

Option: Reverse a posting, if required:

  1. Open the Reverse Journal Entries – In Asset Accounting app.
  2. Select the journal entry.
  3. Specify the mandatory values.
  4. Choose Reverse.

     

Annual Index Maintenance for 2025

According to the 582nd Sequence of the Tax Procedure Law (Vergi Usul Kanunu Genel Tebliği, Sıra No: 582, published 15.02.2025), inflation accounting will not be applied for the first, second, and third provisional tax periods of 2025 (except for certain exempt taxpayers such as jewelers).
This change means that for 2025, the adjustment will only be performed once at the end of the year (31.12.2025).

Source: TÜRMOB – 2025 Yılı Geçici Vergi Dönemlerinde Enflasyon Düzeltmesi Yapılmayacak 

Following the legal change in February 2025, inflation accounting in Türkiye is now applied annually, not monthly or quarterly.
For 2025, the calculation will be based on the difference between the index value as of 31.12.2024 and the index value as of 31.12.2025.

Since no interim calculation is legally required, companies may enter “0” for the index values from January to November and enter the actual year-end value only in December.

This ensures that the adjustment is calculated exclusively at year-end, as required by law.

Disclaimer: This approach is based on current interpretations. Customers are responsible for verifying its legal validity for their specific case and ensuring compliance from both a regulatory and audit perspective.

 

Automated Index Maintenance via API

Instead of manually maintaining index values in the Maintain Asset Revaluation Index app, you can automate the process using the API API_ASSETREVALUATIONINDEX.
The API allows you to manage both the index header (ID, type, country/currency, unit of measure) and the monthly values (Valid From, Valid To, Index Value) programmatically.

 

Use Case
For example, companies can implement an SAP BTP integration or a partner app that retrieves official TÜİK data each month, validates it, and automatically writes it to their SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition system. This removes the need for manual entry and ensures consistent, repeatable index maintenance.

Further Information: API Documentation on SAP Help Portal 

Automated Calculation via BadI

The BAdI FAA_DC_UPA_CUSTOMER with the method SET_PERCENT_VALUE can be used to define formulas for calculating percentage changes automatically.

Example:

Adjustment Coefficient = ((Index value current month / Index value previous month) – 1) * 100

Important: While both SET_PERCENT_VALUE and SET_BASE_VALUE methods are available as of 508, there is a known limitation when using them in scenarios with Periodic Revaluation and Depreciation Split.
In such scenarios, customers should not use the BAdI until this gap is resolved.

Further Information: Overview of Changes in Extensibility Objects 

Support

If you’d like to use the new index type in Türkiye, please create a support incident using the component FI-LOC-FI-TR. To use the feature for other supported countries, use the relevant components.

For more information, refer to the documentation on SAP Help Portal: Maintain Asset Revaluation Index  and Index Type "Replacement Value, Monthly".

Conclusion

The new functionality in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508 allows Turkish companies to comply with the legal requirements for inflation accounting and index-based revaluation of assets.

entry.title: Re: Asset depreciation adjustment based on APC
entry.content:
Great question 👍

Yes — in SAP Asset Accounting (FI-AA) you can maintain time-dependent useful life in the asset master, but you need to be aware of how SAP treats it:

🔹 1. Time-Dependent Data in Asset Master

 In AS02 → Time-Dependent Tab, you can create new validity intervals for asset parameters (cost center, location, depreciation terms, useful life, etc.).

 For example:

   Interval 01.04.2022 – 31.03.2024 → Useful life = 5 years (original).

   Interval 01.04.2025 → Useful life = 10 years (changed).

This means you can split useful life by validity periods.

 🔹 2. What SAP Does with This

 SAP will recalculate depreciation prospectively only.

 It will not retroactively adjust past posted depreciation, even though you maintain intervals.

 In your case:

   It will still depreciate the NBV (24k) over the remaining 7 years (\~3.34k/year).

   It will not go back and restate the first 3 years at \$6k each.

🔹 3. What You Need for Your Requirement

Since you want the system to behave as if the asset was always 10 years from the start, you need two steps:

  1. Maintain new interval in AS02

    Go to AS02 → Time-Dependent → Create new validity starting FY25.

    Enter new useful life (10 years).

    This ensures the system spreads depreciation prospectively.

  1. Adjustment Posting

    Post the over-depreciated portion (\$18k) as a write-up (ABAAL) in FY25.

    After that, system will continue with the new planned depreciation (\$6k/year).

🔹 4. Alternative (Advanced)

Some companies handle this by:

 Creating a parallel depreciation area with the corrected useful life (10 years from beginning).

 The delta (–18k) between the main area and adjustment area can then be picked up and posted as a correction.

 

✅ Answer to your direct question:

Yes, you can add a new interval for useful life in the asset master data.

❌ But this alone will not generate the retroactive \$18k adjustment — you must post that separately.

entry.title: Advanced Early Order Enrichment in SAP Order Management Foundation
entry.content:
You’re implementing SAP Order Management Foundation (OMF), a powerful engine for your order lifecycle. But what happens when standard processing isn't enough? Since OMF is a public cloud solution, extensibility options are limited by design. Your business needs to run a complex fraud check, pull in rich product data from a PIM, or verify export compliance before an order gets triggered for fulfillment. How do you inject this critical, custom logic without breaking the standard OMF processing flow?

The answer isn't a complex, high-risk custom development project. It’s a clever and elegant use of the framework OMF gives you with the concepts of Flow and the "Order transfer Hold". 

Meet the "Early Order Enrichment Pattern" — a powerful technique to (shortly) pause, enhance, and then seamlessly resume order processing. Let's dive into how you can use it to build sophisticated, decoupled extensions that supercharge your OMF instance. 

The Challenge: Breaking Out of the Standard Processing Flow

SAP OMF is designed to orchestrate a streamlined, end-to-end process: order ingestion, sourcing, fulfillment, subsequent processing. But real-world commerce is messy. You might need to ask:

  • Is this high-value order fraudulent?
  • Does this order item have all the details and specs the fulfillment system needs?
  • Can we legally ship this product to the customer's location?

Trying to bolt this logic onto a live, moving process is risky. You could create race conditions, data integrity nightmares, or process orders that should have been stopped. You need a safe window to work your magic.

The Solution: Press Pause with the OMF Flow Framework and the Transfer On Hold Capability

As a prerequisite for the "Early Order Enrichment Pattern", you must enable the Transfer Hold (TOH) capability. The transfer hold delays the order orchestration process to provide a period during which orders can be changed or canceled. This capability is enabled through a setting in the market:

  • transferHoldEnabled, set this parameter to true to enable the capability. Please note, that if this parameter is set to false, there is no way to enable the holding period for individual orders.
  • transferHoldDuration, this parameter controls in minutes the default holding period of an order that is created. Please note, that you should set a period, that is long enough to prevent unwanted continuation. The holding period can actively be ended via API call, so there is no need to set a "short and aggressive" holding period. We would rather recommend to set a longer period.

The process management component of this pattern is the OMF Flow Framework. This standard tool, configured via the Manage Flows app, is your command center. Every Flow is built on three simple concepts:

  • Triggers: An event that kicks off a process (like a new order).
  • Actions: The work to be done (like calling an API or updating a field).
  • Controls: The "if/then" logic that directs the traffic.

The "Early Order Enrichment Pattern" orchestrates these components with a simple, brilliant move: as soon as an order is created, we put it On Hold. The rest of the magic is the managed by listening and raising system events and custom order activities.

Why is this so powerful? An "On Hold" status acts as a protective shield. It stops the order from proceeding to standard fulfillment, giving you a controlled, isolated time window to perform any and all custom logic without interference. Events let you then control the reaction and the next activity.

How It Works: A Chain of Command for Your Data

With the order safely paused, we trigger a cascade of enrichment steps. Think of it as a relay race where each runner passes the baton to the next.

Here’s the play-by-play:

1. The Starting Gun & The First Check (e.g., Fraud Detection)

  • Trigger: The race begins when a new order is created.
  • Action: Call for Backup. The flow triggers the NEEDS_FRAUD_CHECK activity by calling your external fraud detection service via either an OMF Workflow or an SAP Integration Suite iFlow.
  • Action: Pass the Baton. The fraud score comes back. The flow updates the order and changes the Activity to READY_FOR_PIM_ENRICHMENT. The first leg of the race is done.

2. The Relay Continues (e.g., Product Enrichment)

  • Trigger: The READY_FOR_PIM_ENRICHMENT activity is the signal for the next runner.
  • Action: Get the Details. This new flow calls your PIM system, pulling in rich product descriptions, images, or technical specs.
  • Action: Pass the Baton (Again). The flow injects this new data into the order items and sets the next Activity, like ENRICHMENT_COMPLETE

3. Make sure the runner still holds the baton (e.g., Check result of previous step)

  • Trigger: The SAP_ORDERCHANGED_PREFULFILLMENT activity is the signal for the next runner.
  • Action: Check the status of the update. Since patching an order as an asynchronous API, you should check whether the order has been correctly updated by checking the status of the update or even check the enriched content.
  • Action: Pass the Baton (Again). The flow sets then the next Activity, like ENRICHMENT_COMPLETE

You can chain as many of these steps as you need—compliance checks, license verification, custom calculations—each one a clean, self-contained flow triggered by the previous one's activity.

4. The Finish Line: Release the Order

  • Trigger: The final activity, ENRICHMENT_COMPLETE, is set.
  • Action: Go, Go, Go! The final flow in our chain performs one last, critical action: it ends the "TOH" status.
  • Result: The shield is lowered. The order—now fully enriched, validated, and ready—is released back into the standard OMF process for fulfillment, smarter and safer than before.

Why You’ll Love This Pattern

This isn't just a workaround; it's a superior architectural choice.

  • Bulletproof Control: The "TOH" status guarantees that incomplete or unverified orders never accidentally slip through to fulfillment.
  • Ultimate Flexibility: Is your business adding a new compliance check next year? Just build a new flow and insert it into the chain. No need to touch your existing logic.
  • Clear Visibility: Each step is a distinct flow that can be monitored in the Manage Flows app. Troubleshooting becomes a breeze.
  • Decoupled & Clean: Your custom logic (iFlows, microservices) lives outside OMF. This allows specialized teams to work independently and keeps your OMF core pristine.

By mastering the "Early Order Enrichment Pattern," you transform SAP OMF from a standard processor into a dynamic, intelligent, and extensible platform ready for any business challenge you throw at it.

Conceptual Diagram

This swim lane illustrates various process steps and indicates their locations. While the OMF flow framework is depicted as a separate lane, it's integrated within the OMF solution to clarify the sequence of events.

OMF oversees the order, the flow framework handles all enhancement steps, the technical connections are managed by the Integration suite, and the specific logic and data, being independent, can be hosted anywhere.

 

Practical Use Cases

The usecases of this pattern are endless. Here are a few examples to spark your inspiration:

  • Advanced Fraud Detection: Call an external, specialized fraud detection service with order and customer details. Place the order on permanent hold if fraud is detected.
  • Product Data Enrichment: For items with only a SKU, call a Product Information Management (PIM) system to pull in full descriptions, technical specifications, images, or compliance data required by the fulfillment system.
  • License and Compliance Checks: For software or regulated goods, call an external service to verify licenses or check export/import compliance before releasing the order for fulfillment.

Benefits of this Approach

  • Flexibility & Extensibility: Add any number of complex business rules without modifying the OMF core application.
  • Decoupled Architecture: The custom logic (iFlows, microservices) is developed and maintained separately from OMF, allowing for independent updates and specialized teams.
  • Leverages Standard Features: This pattern uses the intended OMF Flow framework, ensuring stability and compatibility with future OMF upgrades.
  • Controlled & Failsafe Processing: The "TOH" status guarantees that incomplete or unverified orders are not processed, preventing data integrity issues downstream.
  • Transparency & Monitoring: Each step in the cascade can be monitored through the Manage Flows app, providing clear visibility into the enrichment process. In addition, you check your Cloud ALM instance for issues raised by the OMF application. You will find details there on failed updates, creations or any other issue that needs attention. Cloud ALM offers also ways to trigger automated notifications to decrease monitoring efforts and speed up the healing of issues.

entry.title: Re: SAC to ECC Data Retraction
entry.content:
I don't believe it would help in your situation given your exact landscape, so not offering as an 'answer'.

However, we are doing this for our SAC Planning solution. We have SAP BW/4HANA on-prem, ECC6.0 on-prem and also SAP Data Services. We have users do planning in SAC. Once the planning cycle is complete, we have built an interactive story that allows them to define a scope and then click a button to trigger the retraction to ECC.

What actually happens is:

  • The button calls an OData service technical object in the story.
  • The OData service is built in SAP BW and is established to accept parameters and trigger a process chain.
  • The Process Chain invokes a Data Services job to call the Data Export API and push the data into an established ADSO in BW.
  • Once the Data Services job is complete, the process chain has a custom program step that calls an established RFC enabled function module in ECC to deliver the data.
  • The function module in ECC loads the data to FICO PCA.

The OData service that SAC is calling in BW also has a method that returns a status, so SAC is able to poll that method to report the status back to the user in SAC.

Some of this might sound over-engineered, but it is done to leverage existing design patterns, and for various reasons, such as the fact we want the data in BW as well as PCA in ERP.

Cheers, Ivan.

entry.title: Re: Make To Stock MRP set up for each sales order require...
entry.content:
Hello @Mahendra_Kalal 

Your case is explained in the note 550568 - FAQ: Planning run (MD01, MD02, MD03, MDBT,...), question 6:

There are several requirements on one day. Is it possible that the MRP creates a separate procurement proposal for every requirement?

Same as for the daily lot size with a number of periods = 1 (lot size TB), requirements of one day are also grouped into one procurement proposal for the lot-for-lot order quantity (lot size EX) (see documentation for the lot-for-lot order quantity). Separate procurement proposals can be achieved only if you work with make-to-order production. Here, the requirements are managed in separate planning segments of the stock/requirements list.

You should switch to MTO if you need seperate planned orders, clearly assigned to sales orders.

@Lakshmipathi proposal of lot procedure FX and lot size = 1 is a nice workaround if your sales orders are for small quantities. Otherwise you'll end up with a lot of planned orders per single sales order.

Best regards

Dominik Tylczynski

entry.title: AI-Assisted Smart Notes in Manage Project Billing
entry.content:
Hello All,

I am writing this article to give some insights on generative AI assistance features embedded in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud products like Professional Services.

Overview

The Smart Notes feature in the Manage Project Billing app proposes grammatically correct notes for project billing request items that already have notes maintained. Billing specialists need to manually review the maintained notes in the Note field in the Prepare Billing page of the Manage Project Billing app. This process can be very time-consuming because of the high volume of postings.

What's New

With the introduction of the new Smart Notes feature, you can get grammatically correct note proposals for project billing request items. When you accept the proposed notes, the updated notes are available immediately, thereby making the process more efficient.

How to access the feature

To access the Smart Notes feature, your business user needs to have the following authorizations assigned in the business role by an Administrator:

  • Business catalog: Project Billing — Smart Notes Feature (SAP_PS_BC_BILLG_AI_SNOTE_PC)

  • IAM app: Project Billing Request (Object Page) (F4456_SNOTE_TRAN)

  • To access this generative AI feature within SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, an additional entitlement and authorization may be required.

More information can be found here -->https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/ee9ee0ca4c3942068ea584d2f929b5b1/99bb1ef3b5ce46c08e64fcfdc6d3882f.html?state=TEST&version=2508.00
